alert.note: Alert for Cape Decision to Salisbury Sound Coastal Area; Cape Fairweather to Cape Suckling Coastal Area; Eastern Baranof Island and Southern Admiralty Island; Eastern Chichagof Island; Glacier Bay; Salisbury Sound to Cape Fairweather Coastal Area (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued September 01 at 2:17PM AKDT by NWS Juneau
info.description: ...HEAVY RAIN FOR LATE WEEK INTO THE WEEKEND FOR GULF COAST AND ICY STRAIT CORRIDOR... An atmospheric river has started moving across the northern half of Southeast Alaska. Heavy rain started late Wednesday night near Yakutat, and is expected to slide over the Icy Strait corridor and central gulf coast on Friday. So far today, the Yakutat airport has received about 1.9 inches of rain. The heavier rain is expected to last through Saturday morning before starting to diminish Saturday afternoon. From early Thursday to Saturday around 5 to 8 inches of rainfall is expected over the Northeast Gulf Coast including Yakutat. The highest rain rates are expected on Thursday and again late Friday and Saturday. The northern inner channels including the Icy Strait corridor will see somewhat lesser amounts ranging from 2 to 5 inches of rainfall with the highest amounts in the region from Cross Sound to Juneau. The highest rain rates will be Friday Night into Saturday though the area around Pelican and Glacier Bay could see heavier rainfall on Thursday as well. There are some uncertainties in the total rainfall forecast as terrain could cause some local areas to get more or less rainfall. Local rivers and streams are expected to rise as a result of this rainfall. At this time, flood potential is low, but rivers may reach or get near bankfull conditions. People who recreate along rivers and streams across the northern panhandle should remain alert. For any updated information on this evolving event visit weather.gov/juneau.
